Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The monastery’s once-a-year festival begins at dawn and needs committed volunteers for preparations.
Story: I woke before sunrise, the air still cool as I slipped on my uniform and prepared my cleaning cart. Today was the monastery’s annual festival, a day I cherished as a Buddhist, when the community gathered for rituals and shared meals. I had promised to help with the preparations, to sweep the temple grounds and arrange offerings before the first chant. But as a housekeeping cleaner, I was also scheduled for a deep clean at the hospital, a task that required strict adherence to safety and hygiene protocols. I knew I should wear gloves for every task, but sometimes, in the rush, I skipped them for smaller jobs. My supervisor had warned me: “No shortcuts, not even once.” The hospital was short-staffed, and my absence would be noticed. Yet, the monks were counting on me too, and my heart ached at the thought of missing the festival’s opening prayers. I stood in my small kitchen, torn between the expectations of my work and my faith, feeling the weight of both uniforms pressing on my shoulders.
